byline.contributor: Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting from Beijing and Shigezhuang, Hebei. Julie Hirschfeld Davis contributed reporting from Washington. Kiki Zhao contributed research from Beijing.

abstract: Rise of Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin, richest person in Asia with estimated fortune of more than $35 billion, offers glimpse into way business and power intersect in country; reviews of corporate records of Wanda Group, Wang's conglomerate, shows that company benefited from having relatives of Communist Party elite as early investors, such as Qi Qiaoqiao, sister of Pres Xi Jinping; Wang has translated success in real estate to culture and entertainment sector and is in position to advance Beijing's interests abroad.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of some of China’s most powerful politicians and their business associates own significant stakes in companies of Wang Jianlin, Asia’s richest man.

headline.main: Wang Jianlin, a Billionaire at the Intersection of Business and Power in China
headline.print_headline: Billionaire at the Intersection of China’s Business and Power

snippet: Relatives of some of China’s most powerful politicians and their business associates own significant stakes in companies of Wang Jianlin, Asia’s richest man.
